prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Effect of Transfer: Proceedings in the Transferee Court

para.paratext: Parties have argued to the Panel that only certain issues should be transferred for consolidated or coordinated pretrial proceedings and that certain issues should remain for consideration by the court in which the actions were initially filed. The Panel has generally rejected these arguments.

In an early case the Panel refused to leave the question of class action certification[1] for the transferor court while transferring all nonclass pretrial issues.[2] The Panel concluded that it lacked power to order limited transfer and that, in any event, such separation of issues would be “unwise and indiscrete.”[3] Similarly, the Panel rejected an attempt to transfer only discovery proceedings relating to liability, leaving all damage questions in the transferor court. The Panel stated:

We will not so restrict the transferee judge for we think it more conducive to effective judicial management to allow him to determine which issues are appropriate for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings and which should be reserved for further proceedings following remand.[4]
The Panel has relied on the legislative history of 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407 in determining that the transferee court should be allowed unbridled control over the transferred actions until remand occurs.[5]

Where the Panel considers many actions of different types, it may order transfer of only some of them for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings. For example, in one case the Panel ordered transfer of certain antitrust and securities cases but refused to transfer a separate declaratory judgment action arising from the same set of facts and sharing common facts.[6] The Panel considered the argument by the parties in the securities cases that transfer should also not be ordered in those cases, but rejected the argument. The Panel stated:

Viewing this litigation as a whole, we rule that any inconvenience claimed by [one securities action defendant] to result from the fact that it is a party in only one of the actions being transferred is outweighed by the overall benefits of coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings in these actions.[7]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

See Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(c)(1). Class certification motions are discussed in greater detail in 7 Charles Alan Wright, Arthur R. Miller & Mary Kay Kane, Federal Practice and Procedure (3rd ed. 2001 & Supp. 2012) and David F. Herr, Roger S. Haydock & Jeffrey W. Stempel, Motion Practice§ 12.02 (8th ed. 2018).
In re Plumbing Fixture Cases, 298 F. Supp. 484, 487–88 (J.P.M.L. 1968); see also In re Antibiotic Drugs, 299 F. Supp. 1403, 1406 (J.P.M.L. 1969).

298 F. Supp. at 488. Partial transfer is, however, complete and comprehensive transfer of the actions transferred. All pretrial proceedings in the transferred cases are conducted by the transferee court and all pretrial proceedings in the case or cases not transferred are conducted in the transferor court. This procedure parallels that upon 28 U.S.C.A. § 1404(a) transfer, for that transfer must be for all proceedings. See In re Flight Transp. Corp. Securities Litigation, 764 F.2d 515 (8th Cir. 1985).
In re San Juan, Puerto Rico Air Crash Disaster, 316 F. Supp. 981, 982 (J.P.M.L. 1970).
See In re Plumbing Fixture Cases, 298 F. Supp. 484, 490–91 (J.P.M.L. 1968). The legislative history of 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407 is discussed in § 2:3. See also § 9:4 n.3 supra and accompanying quotation.
